results.title: Book keeper
results.creator_credit: Michael Cusack, Richard Chataway and Anifex Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: Within the surreal confines of an old-fashioned bookstore, an eccentric proprietor wages a constant battle against time, insects and the occasional customer to maintain his beloved collection of books. Above the dusty store, his crippled Granny waits for him to supply her with a tin of her favourite Irish Stew as she knits and devours televised rock and roll wrestling. Things take a bizarre twist as a mysterious “book-worm” wriggles into Granny’s ear, making her crave the work of T.S. Eliot. Winner, Best Animation, ZOOM! SA Shorts Fest 1999.

results.title: Boo Boo monster enters a beauty contest
results.creator_credit: Bill Cleary and Billy Budd Films
results.brief_description: A beautifully animated story about a friendly green monster who tries to change the colour of his skin and who learns he must accept himself as he really is. A rhythmic drum beat enhances the natural rhythm of the verse to which visuals are set. Animated by Tom Golden and Arnie Levey, music performed and composed by Herbert Harris.

results.title: Bonza
results.creator_credit: David Swann, Deborah Hoare, Bonza Productions and Film Victoria
results.brief_description: Bonza is quite possibly the funniest Australian short film ever! Being the confidante to an average suburban family is finally more than a dog can bear! “A gloriously silly climax” - top acting, brilliant script and direction make this a real little barker.

results.title: Bonds and relationships. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country education Project-Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: A panel led by Peter Couchman, (Don Edgar, Institute of Family Affairs Jenni Strauss and Dr. Christopher Worth, Monash University and Colin Goodwin of Philip Institute) discuss the HSC literature theme which concentrates on the family and the connections which operate within families. In Part 1 the texts “Father and son” by Edmund Gosse and “Long day’s journey into night” by Eugene O’Neill are considered. Covers such topics as the changing mix of families, the stress of being oneself in a family relationship and yet still being part of a family, and the kinds of support available for people facing problems. Part 2 looks at more contemporary issues that affect family relationships. The texts “The Millstone” by Margaret Drabble and “A Very easy death” by Simone de Beauvoir are considered.

results.title: Bon Voyage (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Upon the cruise ship “Mara” - bound for Hong Kong out of San Francisco - an oddly assorted group of travellers dine together at the Captain’s table. Here the basis of a developing web of relationships is laid and made all the more intimate and public by the inevitably close world a sea voyage creates. Starring Nigel Havers and Judy Parfitt Based on the original by Noel Coward. Rated: PG

results.title: Bombay movies
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our Asian neighbours: India”.
Vinod Kharna is one of the most popular Hindi movie stars in Bombay’s film industry. This film explores his life and work as a way of gaining insight into Indian “pop culture”.

results.title: Bomb threat strategy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safetycare”
Preventative measures, what to look for, search procedures, assessing the threat, the telephone call, when to evacuate and the correct evacuation procedures are the key points covered in this video.

results.title: Bolivia: the tin mountain
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, David Elstein and Thames Television
results.brief_description: A moving presentation showing the desperate poverty in the lives of the tin miners of Bolivia. Notes the problems of lack of capital, absentee ownership of the tin mines, market forces and the political system which influence the prices of tin and hence the life style of the miners. Narrated by Jonathan Dimbleby. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: BOLD = Blind outdoor leisure development
results.brief_description: At Aspen, in the Rocky Mountains, U.S.A., an organisation called Blind Outdoor Leisure Development enables blind people to participate in many sports. With experienced guides, 500 blind people are involved in all kinds of sports, including skiing, ice-skating, horseriding, fishing, mountain climbing, rafting in the Colorado rapids, and experiencing wildlife. Narrated by John Denver. Suitable for secondary school level.
